{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3326432,"name":"Vivienne","username":"Craftyhippie","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/779978/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T02:15:51.470Z","cooked":"

My team, 3966 is having trouble with out arm lifting mechanism that is heavily inspired by the quokkas. Our chain sometimes slips as well as our gears aren’t fully aligning sometimes and make a sort of clicking sound. Our bolts holding the large sprocket in are beginning to bend as well. What are some ways to improve this lifting mechanism?

IMG_56831920×1280 207 KB

we had some problems like this on our robot as well. i recommend you tu make a support on the two sides of all the axis for them to not bend. make sure that the pinion and sprocket are locked in place as well and have a good conection with the arm/ motor

I agree. I would want to constrain the free ends of those axles in bearings in a plate. Can you see the gears trying to move apart (even a tiny bit) as a reaction to the torque?

I would recommend driving the smaller sprocket directly from the gearboxes if possible. My team also has a Quokkas design and uses a 64:1 reduction to drive a 12T sprocket that is connected to the 60T sprocket on the arm. We also use springs attached to the chain to assist with the lifting of the arm.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T03:28:21.633Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":28.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457658,"topic_slug":"help-with-arm-lifting-mechanism","display_username":"Britt C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46267,"username":"john3928","name":"John Hascall (he)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/john3928/{size}/143275_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33908,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4488 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/help-with-arm-lifting-mechanism/457658/5","custom_user_title":"4488 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3326578,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T05:17:31.954Z","cooked":"

We have a really similar setup, and two things helped us:

  1. The outer plate on the cantilevered gears that was already mentioned.

  2. Drill a hole or two into the sprocket and 2x1, put a spacer in the gap, and bolt them together, to link them together at a point further out from the center of the pivot. Right now the lever arm to transfer the power from the sprocket to the arm is like, 2 inches out from the pivot on the hub, which is good for speed, but bad for strength. If you add a point further out, it’ll have more leverage and not bend bolts (as much).

image1441×962 127 KB

Our team has also worked through similar issues. The suggestions above are good to work on. As well for the chain, check out this link
Roller Chain Climbing Sprockets? Causes and Solutions - Baart Group.

No need to specifically calculate anything but work to improve your chain mechanism in these areas:
Tooth engagement
Chain wrap
Chain tension

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T14:17:07.405Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":105,"readers_count":104,"score":21.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457658,"topic_slug":"help-with-arm-lifting-mechanism","display_username":"Joe","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://baartgroup.com/roller-chain-climbing-sprockets/#:~:text=Chain%20jumping%20could%20be%20a,as%20it%20completes%20the%20rotation","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Roller Chain Climbing Sprockets? Causes and Solutions - Baart Group","clicks":6}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64877,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/help-with-arm-lifting-mechanism/457658/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3327877,"name":"Kara Bakowski","username":"Karibou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/karibou/{size}/193241_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T17:07:37.544Z","cooked":"

Depending on the motion of your arm, you may be able to add a counterbalance/counterweight to it - small gas springs, surgical tubing, constant force springs, etc.

Adding a plate between the two sprocket shafts (similar to what @Britt showed for the gears) may also help stop chain skipping.

Also, fair warning, as you start implementing the other suggestions in thread, you are potentially moving your failure points to other places in the mechanism, so don’t be shocked if other things start breaking. My guess is that the next weakest point is the shaft, so keep a close eye on that for twisting.
